ECONOMICS relating to a situation in which the amount of a product sold or supplied changes very little in relation to the product's price: Cereal prices are considered "inelastic," meaning that a 10-percent price increase tends to boost supplies by only one or two percentage points. Supply of oil is notoriously inelastic: it can only respond slowly to price changes. Compare
elastic
